Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Nash Equilibrium Problems under Uncertainty

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nash Equilibrium (NE) models provide the mathematical basis to study the interdependence between decision-makers in a competitive environment. These models provide insights into the operations of many multi-agent socio-technical systems, which include communications, electric power, and transportation networks. These socio-technical systems must not only accommodate technical constraints (e.g., physical laws of electrical power flow), but must also acknowledge the goals of several decision-makers, all of whom make choices under uncertainty and compete with their rivals. As a concrete example, consider the modern electricity network: some generation is carried out by large units, whereas distributed generation and storage may be operated by individuals, and transmission and distribution assets are operated by system operators and utilities. In addition, the growing penetration of renewable energy (highly volatile), the uncertainty about fuel prices, new technology, and energy policy, create a challenging setting in which the firms and/or individuals operate. This project, which combines the need to incorporate system constraints, as well as the effects of risk and uncertainty in the absence of cooperation across decision-makers, will address some of the most challenging questions regarding the structure, algorithms, scalability, and interpretations for NE models under uncertainty. The broader impact of the project includes the study of markets in power and communication networks, and the training and education of graduate students.

Current theories and algorithmic schemes are relatively restrictive in their ability to accommodate risk measures, hierarchical and recourse-based decision-making, and coupled strategy sets. Motivated by these lacunae, this research will utilize a broad framework that can accommodate both private and coupled constraints, allows for linear, quadratic and convex models for taking recourse, and captures risk-aversion through the incorporation of composite and deviation-based risk measures. The goals of this research include the following: (i) Analysis: Verifiable statements for the existence and uniqueness of the resulting equilibria through the analysis of the resulting risk-based variational and quasi-variational inequality problems; (ii) Algorithms: Design, analysis (convergence, complexity) and statistical properties of estimators derived on algorithms reliant on joint sampling and approximation schemes; and (iii) Applications: Problems in electricity markets and other areas of planning under competition and uncertainty will be considered in two-stage and hierarchical settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed research agenda of this grant focused on the development of algorithmic tools for computing equilibria of Nash games complicated by uncertainty. This set of questions lies at the boundary of two well-studied research areas: (i) Noncooperative game-theory, a field that focuses on the interactions between a collection of selfish users; and (ii) Stochastic programming, a sub-field of optimization that investigates the solution of problems complicated by uncertainty. As part of this research grant, we have developed models and algorithms for addressing convex Nash games complicated by the presence of uncertainty. Such problems are not merely of theoretical interest but are of particular relevance in the context of electricity markets, traffic networks, telecommunication networks, amongst others. Our focus lay on developing a broad class of schemes based on the nature of the underlying game-theoretic problem and leveraged Monte-Carlo sampling theory to further improve the rates of convergence of the produced sequence of iterates. The key outcomes of this grant are as follows: (i) Development of rate statements for synchronous and asynchronous best-response algorithms for stochastic Nash games complicated by uncertainty under an assumption of a contractive best-response map. (ii) Development of variance-reduced best-response and gradient-response schemes under diverse assumptions (i.e. contractive best-response maps, monotonicity etc.) that achieve deterministic rates of convergence when sample-size is raised at suitable rates. (iii) Development of first-order schemes for potential stochastic Nash games and their misspecified variants. (iv) Development of distributed variants of gradient-response and best-response schemes for a subclass of games (namely aggregative) that achieve deterministic rates of convergence, a consequence of harnessing variance reduction and increasing rounds of communication. Succinctly, the intellectual merit of this work lies in the development of techniques for a range of stochastic Nash games under a range of intricacies with a breadth of algorithmic requirements with the overarching goal of obtaining convergence guarantees and rate statements, that often match deterministic counterparts. The broader impact of this work will be felt in regimes where game-theoretic models have been employed for examining the role of market power and assessing the welfare implications of market design, such as in the context of power markets, amongst others. In addition, there has been a recent interest in modeling a range of distributed resource allocation problems as Nash games and the aforementioned results are expected to significantly impact such efforts. Finally, this grant has aided in the enhancement of the course offerings in industrial engineering, particularly in the context of stochastic optimization and equilibrium programming.
